title: 108_s2818
content: There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so the curr_chunk cannot be summarized. Congress finds that the right to vote is fundamental under the Constitution and aims to encourage every eligible American to vote by eliminating obstacles and discrimination in voting. Congress emphasizes the importance of removing barriers to voting and ensuring fair voter registration processes for all eligible Americans. It is crucial to encourage active participation in the electoral process and provide access to voter registration through a uniform system. Congress has a duty to address equal protection violations in voting systems by enacting legislation based on the Constitution. They must ensure states and localities improve election administration for all Americans to participate in the democratic process. Requirements for voters who do not register in person with a state or local government entity. Requirements for voters who do not register in person with a state or local government entity are amended under the Help America Vote Act of 2002. The definition of "in person" registration is clarified to exclude registrations made by someone other than the individual themselves. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 is amended to clarify that voter registrations made by someone other than the individual themselves are not considered "in person." This amendment also includes a conforming amendment to the heading of subsection (b) of section 303. The effective date for these amendments is specified. Increased penalties for fraudulent voter registration involving 10 or more violations. Increased penalties for fraudulent voter registration involving 10 or more violations include a fine of $20,000 and up to ten years in prison for each violation under the Voting Rights Act of 1965. Similarly, under the National Voter Registration Act of 1993, individuals or organizations found in violation may face a fine of $500,000 ($1,000,000 for organizations) or up to 10 years in prison, or both. The amendments made by this section shall apply to violations occurring after the date of the enactment of this Act, with penalties including imprisonment up to 10 years and fines paid into the Treasury fund.
